summary: An email from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to an attorney named Jack, forwarding a court order from Judge Alison Nathan. The order reminds counsel in the United States v. Maxwell case to comply with local court rules regarding the handling of sensitive materials, as the indictment has been expanded.

persons.name: Jack
persons.context: Recipient of an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding a court order and compliance with local rules in the United States v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Issued a court order in the United States v. Maxwell case reminding attorneys to comply with SDNY Local Rule 23.1 regarding sensitive materials.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Sender of the email, forwarding Judge Nathan's order and reminding the recipient attorney about compliance with local court rules.

connections.description: The prosecutor is communicating a court order and legal compliance reminder to the attorney.
Judge Nathan issued a court order that applies to all attorneys, including Jack, in the United States v. Maxwell case.

events.title: Judge Nathan Issues Order on Local Rule Compliance
events.description: Judge Alison Nathan issued an order reminding counsel for parties and witnesses to comply with SDNY Local Rule 23.1 regarding the handling of sensitive materials.

events.title: Prosecutor Forwards Court Order to Attorney
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emailed attorney Jack to forward Judge Nathan's order and remind him of compliance obligations, noting the Maxwell indictment had been expanded.

keyFacts: The indictment in United States v. Maxwell (20 Cr. 330) has been expanded, triggering the application of a prior court order to all attorneys involved.
Judge Alison Nathan issued an order on July 23, 2020, reminding counsel to comply with SDNY Local Rule 23.1 concerning sensitive materials.
The communication is a procedural notice from a federal prosecutor to a defense attorney about compliance with court rules.
The email originates from the U.S. Attorney's Office at St. Andrew's Plaza in the Southern District of New York.
